newsitem.title: USA: Republicans say Clinton playing politics with parks.
newsitem.headline: Republicans say Clinton playing politics with parks.

text.p: Senate Republicans angrily accused President Clinton Friday of using a national parks bill that would affect 41 states to punish his opponents.

"This is a power-play to punish the states where the president's ratings are not high enough," Sen. Hank Brown of Colorado said. "This is wrong politics to punish those who won't go along" in Clinton's re-election bid, he said.

Meanwhile, talks were continuing to try to salvage the national parks bill after the White House sent its sponsors a long list of objections including provisions for corporations to become licensed national parks sponsors, a parks entrance fee hike and a number of boundary changes and land transfers that critics said gave sweet deals to special interests.
Environmental groups opposed the bill, saying a number of objectionable provisions had been added to it. They also opposed the corporate sponsorship plan, saying it would commercialize the parks.

But Senate Republican aides said the White House was threatening to veto the bill for some provisions that it initially supported -- such as parks fund-raising measures -- and was singling out initiatives sponsored by Republicans.

Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee Chairman Frank Murkowski accused the White House of conducting a strategy of "cherrypicking" the items it wanted, then plotting to force Congress to include them in its sweeping spending bill while other measures died.

"Here we are, picking the bones of this legislation," the Alaska Republican said. He said he opposed efforts to include selected items in a broad spending bill while killing the huge package of projects that House and Senate conferees agreed to.

Reading a list of sponsors of measures the White House sought to delete, Murkowski said, "It's rather intersting to identify who's on these because there's a certain amount of partisanship that you can't help but see as a reality."

Measures backed by the White House and environmentalists included establishing a trust to manage the former Presidio military installation as a park in San Francisco, protecting the Sterling Forest on the New York-New Jersey border and establishing a tallgrass prairie reserve in Kansas.
Senate aides said talks to break the impasse continued while Democrats used technical procedures to bar Murkowski from bringing the the bill to the floor.
"If there is an agreement in principle on how to solve the problems, then these procedural problems will melt away," a Republican aide said.
With Congress to adjourn early next week, congressional sources said the House likely would be able to move quickly on the bill if a deal was reached with the administration.
At midday, White House Chief of Staff Leon Panetta told a reporter: "They are still talking but chances have diminished in the last hour" to include parks measures in the spending bill.
